Under the great pressure of the deep ocean, the methane becomes trapped as methane gas hydrates, which are crystalline materials in which methane molecules are surrounded by a cage of water molecules.
Methane hydrates are of interest as a potential source of natural gas.
Bovine methanogenesis diverts carbon from meat production, and it makes a significant contribution to global methane.

The basis of the connection is not known, but Hansen speculates that specific methanogens couple with specific clostridia-like bacteria to provide the hydrogen gas needed for methanogenesis.
Cattle support methanogenesis within their rumen and reticulum (a common veterinary trick is to insert a tube into the rumen and ignite the escaping methane gas).
Termites have to aerate their mounds continually in order to remove methane; when rainfall temporarily clogs the mound, the mound can be ignited by lightning and explode.
